channel.title: Beginning With Programming
channel.description:
Ok well heres pretty much the story, if you don't have time to read it just ignore this topic. Next semester (which is about 1 month away) I will be taking AP computer science. Course description at the bottom. It doesn't say it, but I will be programming in Java, which I have no experince (unless you are retarded and count private servers which was 3-5 years ago). Overall I don't really have much knowledge with programming in general....I took 2 classes in Visual Basic (which was called Programming 1 and Programming 2) but that was just mostly making useless applications, so I don't count that. I really need to know how an operating system works so I can better understand programming. I don't want to be completely fucked when I get into the class and I am probably going to be going to University in 2011-2015 for a BS in some computer field (computer science, computer engineering, etc...). All I am asking is where you would tell a person (assumming they had no knowledge of how a computer works or computer programming) to go to start with learning how a computer opearting system works, and where to get started with programming (java). I know someone of you will say the java docs website, but I prefer books and not internet resources (even though alot are good). So If any of you could tell me of any books to get started with (ebooks maybe) and if you must some websites. I would like to have the BASICS down in a week at most. I need to glance over my grammar book and calc book with the remaining time before school.
AP Computer Science A Course Code: 25084 Course Level: Advanced Placement Course Offering: Year-long for 1 credit Course Description This course differs from the A/B class in depth, scope, and pace. This AP Computer Science course is an introductory course in computer science. Because the development of computer programs to solve problems is a skill fundamental to the study of computer science, a large part of the course is built around the development of computer programs or parts of programs that correctly solve a given problem. The course also emphasizes the design issues that make programs understandable, adaptable, and, when appropriate, reusable. At the same time, the development of useful computer programs and classes is used as a context for introducing other important concepts in computer science, including the development and analysis of algorithms, the development and use of fundamental data structures, and the study of standard algorithms and typical applications. Computer Science A emphasizes object-oriented programming methodology with an emphasis on problem solving and algorithm development and is meant to be the equivalent of a first-semester course in computer science. It also includes the study of data structures and abstraction, but these topics are not covered to the extent that they are covered in Computer Science AB. For more information on the content covered by the AP course and exam, please visit: http://www.collegeboard.org/ap/students/compsci/index.html This class is available to any student who has completed Algebra I and is interested in learning to program at the college level. This is a college level class and will move at a considerably faster pace than the typical high school class. Students should be prepared to complete outside readings and spend many hours on the computer. You must be willing to share and help classmates throughout this class with their programming assignments. The instructor will monitor the support given to students and will intervene only when necessary.

item.title: Beginning With Programming
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

[quote=“Tekk, post:10, topic:349148”][quote author=mwiebelhaus link=topic=445519.msg3277135#msg3277135 date=1279604739]

I took AP Computer Science this past school year (HS freshman, woo), so here’s my input.

The course (at least as taught at my school) did assume a basic knowledge of Java at the beginning. However, they provided a quick review, so people who didn’t know as much as others were brought up to speed.

A lot of the class is just learning general computer science concepts, so Java is really just the tool they use to teach these concepts. If you understand what’s going on (and they will teach you everything) you will have no problem.

And, I got a 5 on the exam
No CS 101 for me in college, heh

NICE, was the ap exam hard…and was the class hard overall?
[/quote]

Class was not hard overall, exam had some tough questions but not too bad. You have to solve all the problems in your head, no compiler allowed. The only one/two I think I missed were crazy recursion questions. There’s also a free response section where you have to write code from scratch. For example, one of the problems was to implement a “Line” class with a constructor and a few methods dealing with whether given points were on the line etc.[/quote]

Well that last thing you just said just took my hide on a ride. Then again I just started learning java and the class is 2 semesters long Thanks for the help though

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Tekk123 Tekk
item.description:
@Tekk123 wrote:

[quote=“mwiebelhaus, post:9, topic:349148”][quote author=Tekk link=topic=445519.msg3277084#msg3277084 date=1279600423]
I took AP Computer Science this past school year (HS freshman, woo), so here’s my input.

The course (at least as taught at my school) did assume a basic knowledge of Java at the beginning. However, they provided a quick review, so people who didn’t know as much as others were brought up to speed.

A lot of the class is just learning general computer science concepts, so Java is really just the tool they use to teach these concepts. If you understand what’s going on (and they will teach you everything) you will have no problem.

And, I got a 5 on the exam
No CS 101 for me in college, heh
[/quote]
NICE, was the ap exam hard…and was the class hard overall?[/quote]

Class was not hard overall, exam had some tough questions but not too bad. You have to solve all the problems in your head, no compiler allowed. The only one/two I think I missed were crazy recursion questions. There’s also a free response section where you have to write code from scratch. For example, one of the problems was to implement a “Line” class with a constructor and a few methods dealing with whether given points were on the line etc.

Read full topic

item.title: Beginning With Programming
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

Unhandled:

ps you don’t need to use any kind of UI to learn the vast majority of programming concepts.

Ok thanks. Its not so much that it gets boring because I cant create a UI, its boring because I can only make useless programs, because I haven’t gotten to the part where I can input shit. But im only 50 pages away so I think I can get through it.

Read full topic

item.title: Beginning With Programming
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

Ok well thanks for all the help. I had a book I bought “Java A Beginners Guide - 4th Edition” when I thought I actually though runescape private servers were cool. I never read it but I started reading it and it makes alot of sense…its still all console apps though till the last 100 pages. http://www.amazon.com/Java-Beginners-Guide-4th-Ed/dp/0072263849

Read full topic

item.title: Beginning With Programming
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

This class is available to any student who has completed Algebra I and is interested in learning to program at the college level. This is a college level class and will move at a considerably faster pace than the typical high school class. Students should be prepared to complete outside readings and spend many hours on the computer. You must be willing to share and help classmates throughout this class with their programming assignments. The instructor will monitor the support given to students and will intervene only when necessary.
It doesn't mention that you need even basic programming knowledge. And the course description says the main part of your course is algorithms and basic data structures, which should be easy enough as long as you're actually taught it and given the relevant books+resources.

Read full topic

item.title: Beginning With Programming
item.dc:creator: @xEnt xEnt
item.description:
@xEnt wrote:

your better off reading a decent java book if you ask me. also why would you need to learn more about ur OS for java? i’ve seen decent programmers that don’t even know a control panel in windows, ive seen programmers that didn’t know what a router was, or a GPU.

Read full topic
